data.text: @MuseWendi @julimsw_juli @wsbgnl Some moms have the worst COVID takes. What's worse is I completely understand why. It's purely emotional.

@wsbgnl And who gives a flying f$ck what people think anyway???  3k a day are dying in the worst pandemic the world has seen in a century. Real public health wouldn't be based on polling. And BTW, remember polls and a certain orange con-artist in 2016?

@PChildermass Public health should galvanize and lead the public to meet ambitious goals. Current public health leaders are fixated on the limits of what is possible. And there are limits, but polls help indicate that the current approach is way undershooting what is feasible.

@lamarshall @wsbgnl maybe. Some people don't speak English (but do they poll them?), some people are illiterate. But assuming infectious is hard to parse for everyone that doesn't have a college degree is a pretty arrogant assumption about credentialing of it's own.
@wsbgnl The term that comes to mind is fake news, but then I start to retch. https://t.co/hytEUBLWoX
@julimsw_juli @wsbgnl i'm more concerned abt employees in outward facing jobs being at risk for wearing masks to protect themselves

@julimsw_juli @wsbgnl go into any mom group on facebook and see how fast they lock down comments if you try to mention anything abt covid mitigation. they allow post after post spewing misinfo but one little comment with facts will get you shut down with the quickness. also anything re: racism

@wsbgnl Reason #1 why quantitative research often fails to accurately report what it's trying to measure: the wording of survey questions is EVERYTHING.

Considering that nearly 40% of Americans have no more than a high school diploma, "infectious" might be hard to parse. https://t.co/Ro9Bdh2Svw
